dmca.title: My work is on your site
dmca.body:
I was working with The Cranberries when pictures or video were taken. It's now displayed on your web site.

 Copyright infringement occurs whenever someone who is not the copyright holder (or a licensee of the copyright holder) exercises one of the exclusive rights. 

 Copyright law takes the form of six rights in areas where the author retains exclusive control. These rights are as follows:
(1) the right of reproduction (i.e., copying),
(2) the right to create derivative works,
(3) the right to distribution,
(4) the right to performance,
(5) the right to display, and
(6) the digital transmission performance right.

 The law of copyright protects the first two rights in both private and public contexts. An author can only restrict the last four rights in the public sphere. Claims of infringement must show that the defendant exercised one of the rights. 

 Please give (my name) of (company) credit.

 Thank you,

_________________________

Is this an appropriate letter for me to send to a competitor using my work to attract business?
Do I first need to copyright my work?
He is in the lighting rental business and so am I.
I do not represent the band, but I set-up the set and the lighting pictured on his web site. He doesn't say it's his work, but I believe it's assumed.
Thanks for your ideas
